Plus you could have just done
[php]if (@$_GET[‘go’])[/php].
[/quote]Or you could do it the right way…

Never block errors just because you can, fix the reason. What matty gave him is completely right.[/quote]
You’re retarded. What Matt posted would still throw an exception!

[quote=“cumescape, post:10, topic:361643”]Edit: Are you retarded?

]It’s better to not end PHP files with ?> unless it’s a snippet inside of a template.

Get out of here until you learn how to code…[/quote]
You’re the retard.
http://www.php.net/manual/en/language.basic-syntax.instruction-separation.php

]It’s better to not end PHP files with ?> unless it’s a snippet inside of a template.

Get out of here until you learn how to code…

item.title: Index.php redirect
item.dc:creator: @chri5 chri5
item.description:
@chri5 wrote:

[quote=“xx matty xx, post:6, topic:361643”][quote author=chri5 link=topic=457914.msg3351015#msg3351015 date=1285326725]
Is this what you mean?

[php]<?php

$link = ‘http://www.google.com’;
if (@$_GET[‘id’] == ‘go’)
header('Location: ’ . $link);
[/php]
[/quote]
What’s with the @?[/quote]
If there’s no index in the _GET array PHP throws a warning/notice.

[quote=“xx matty xx, post:6, topic:361643”][quote author=I james I link=topic=457914.msg3351031#msg3351031 date=1285328232]
Is it possible make that work like

site.com/?go
[/quote]
Yes,
[php]

<?php $link ='http://www.google.com'; if (isset($_GET['go'])) header('Location: ' . $link); ?>

[/php][/quote]
It’s better to not end PHP files with ?> unless it’s a snippet inside of a template. Plus you could have just done
[php]if (@$_GET[‘go’])[/php].

Read full topic

item.title: Index.php redirect
item.dc:creator: @marluxia marluxia
item.description:
@marluxia wrote:

[quote=“chri5, post:5, topic:361643”][quote author=cumescape link=topic=457914.msg3351038#msg3351038 date=1285329271]
Also might i suggest you add “exit();” after your header redirect. It stops the script from phasing the rest of the file.
[/quote]
There’s nothing else in the file…[/quote]

It’s good practice

Read full topic

item.title: Index.php redirect
item.dc:creator: @chri5 chri5
item.description:
@chri5 wrote:

cumescape:

Also might i suggest you add “exit();” after your header redirect. It stops the script from phasing the rest of the file.

There’s nothing else in the file…

[quote=“I james I, post:3, topic:361643”]Is it possible make that work like

site.com/?go[/quote]
Yes, don’t include “index.php” in the url. Or, you could use a rewrite rule to “make that work like” yoursite.com/go/

Read full topic

item.title: Index.php redirect
item.dc:creator: @cumescape cumescape
item.description:
@cumescape wrote:

Yes you can do that as long as its the index page.

Also might i suggest you add “exit();” after your header redirect. It stops the script from phasing the rest of the file.

Read full topic

item.title: Index.php redirect
item.dc:creator: @chri5 chri5
item.description:
@chri5 wrote:

[quote=“I james I, post:1, topic:361643”]How do i make it so that if a user clicks: site.com/?id=go it will redirect them to link i supply in index.php file, so far i have:

[php]<?php
$id=5;
$location=“index.php?id=go”;
header( ‘Location:http://www.google.com’);
?>[/php]

however, this redirects even on root index.
thanks[/quote]
Is this what you mean?

[php]<?php

$link = ‘http://www.google.com’;
if (@$_GET[‘id’] == ‘go’)
header('Location: ’ . $link);
[/php]

Read full topic
